On Thu, Sep 2, 2021 at 1:47 PM Lance Kinney <Lance.Kinney@pels.texas.gov> wrote: Good aSernoon Mr. Kalra,
I have spoken at length with Mr. Sims concerning your situaQon and the opQons we have going forward. Below is an in-depth discussion of several items (note – it is somewhat long but we feel necessary to re-set the foundaQon for this discussion.)
The Board understands your concern with the safety of Anderson Mill Road and your home and your frustraQon with the City of Cedar Park. These are important issues and we will try to assist you in areas in which we have the legal authority and jurisdicQon to do so.
First, I feel some background on the authority, jurisdicQon, and limitaQons of the Board is needed. The Board was created by the Texas Legislature to license professional engineers and assure individuals are complying with the Texas Engineering PracQce Act (TEPA) and Board rules. This authority includes invesQgaQng allegaQons that a licensed engineer has pracQced engineering in a manner that violates TEPA or Board rules or that an unlicensed individual has engaged in the pracQce of engineering.
The Board does not necessarily have any jurisdicQon over acts taken by a professional engineer when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering (for example, a P.E.’s management style or decision making when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering).
  Page 452 of 1607

 The Board also does not have jurisdicQon over ciQes. Each city is its own sovereign jurisdicQon that has oversight of its roads, construcQon requirements, ordinances, internal operaQons, etc. The plans for buildings, roadways, and other engineering projects are not submi]ed to the Board for review or approval and we do not have any role in the acceptance, construcQon, bidding, etc. of a project. We are not involved in the oversight of a city or a city department as to what codes they adopt or implement, or the internal workings of the city itself. The Board does not have the authority to audit a City’s Public Works or Engineering Department or to conduct studies (safety studies, traffic studies, etc). Those are ma]ers under the jurisdicQon of the city itself – the city council, mayor, or whatever structure the city leadership takes. Again, we are charged with the licensure of individual engineers and engineering firms and compliance as it relates directly to the TEPA.
One addiQonal note – as discussed previously, the Board also is not in the posiQon to advocate for or against individuals in disagreements with a city. The Board can invesQgate complaints, but has no role in an individual acQons against a city.
From reviewing the informaQon you have provided, it is clear that you have concerns about the decision making coming out of the City of Cedar Park’s Engineering Department as it relates to Anderson Mill and your home, and want consideraQon from the city (such as a fence or wall, etc.). While the Board can invesQgate violaQons of TEPA, the Board has no authority to ask or demand a City or City Department to take specific acQons. We are not charged with overseeing projects such as roadways – that is the purview of the jurisdicQon itself. For example – for a Texas highway, TXDOT is responsible for the roadway, its design, construcQon, and maintenance. The same framework is in place for roadways within a city – Cedar Park is responsible for its porQon of this road. The Board only has limited jurisdicQon related to municipaliQes. Our jurisdicQon over a city is to ensure that they hire engineers to do engineering work, which the City of Cedar Park seems to have done in this project. The Board does not have the authority to undertake many of the addiQonal tasks of which you are asking (conducQng independent traffic studies or a safety study). This would be something that the city would do, if required by a code, ordinance, law, or other guidance, or if they agree to do so independently.
Based on the informaQon you have provided to date, we also do not see that SecQon 1001.407 of the Texas Engineering PracQce Act has been violated. The law requires that a municipality engage a P.E. for engineering plans, specificaQons, and esQmates. This means engineering plans, engineering specificaQons, and engineering esQmates. It does not call out any parQcular kind of plan or esQmate, such as a safety plan or analysis. It simply means that any engineering work that is done must be done by a P.E. It seems that they have met this requirement through Binkley Barfield or internal engineering staff. As a note, engineering esQmates are generally considered to be the engineering porQon of a materials esQmate, such as quanQQes and grades / specificaQons of different construcQon materials for a project. While the cosQng porQon can be done by an engineer (and if done by an engineer should be signed/sealed), in some instances, the actual pricing of materials would be done by procurement or purchasing staff as they are be]er equipped to know the contracQng and procurement side of things. Non-engineers doing a cost esQmate would not necessarily be considered a violaQon of the TEPA or Board rules.
The City indicated that they have adopted and use the standards published by AASHTO and the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual in designing roads within the city. This type of design is consistent with the Act. If you have concerns that there are specific design problems, a complaint should be filed against the design engineer, who appears to be Gregory Calkins, P.E.
 Page 453 of 1607

 In your communicaQons you also discuss the lack of a sound barrier. For this to be a potenQal violaQon, you would need to provide a local or state code or ordinance that is being violated by not construcQng a sound barrier. The Board understands that you believe such a barrier is warranted, but the lack of the barrier would need to be Qed back to an engineer violaQng a specific local or state code or ordinance.
For the Board to move forward with invesQgaQng a complaint, you would need to provide specific instances and examples, with supporQng documentaQon, of where the design is inconsistent with generally accepted engineering pracQce, is in conflict with the AASHTO standards or the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual, or violates a Board rule. An example might be related to the safety analysis you have menQoned – while TEPA does not mandate any parQcular report or analysis be done, if a safety analysis is required by a standard or code and it was not done or done incorrectly, then it would be something that a P.E. should have done and could be a violaQon.
All of this being said, we are here to invesQgate potenQal violaQons of TEPA as set out above. If you believe that individual engineers made mistakes involving the design of the road or road expansion, then a complaint can be filed against the individual engineers that did the design. If you believe that there are design issues by an engineer at Binkley Barfield, the complaint would be against that individual. If an engineer from the City of Cedar Park made specific mistakes in the pracQce of engineering and in violaQon of TEPA, then we can invesQgate that. Please note a belief that there is a violaQon is not sufficient for the Board to take acQon; you need to indicate a specific code or ordinance that is being violated in the complaint.
One final note - outside of specific engineering issues that are related to violaQons of TEPA and under the jurisdicQon of the Board, we note that it appears many of the other concerns with the engineering department would best be addressed to the city government (city council or mayor) of Cedar Park. It is possible that your State RepresentaQve or State Senator could assist with your issues with the city.
I know this is a long email with a lot of informaQon, but please understand that there are restricQons on the jurisdicQon of the Board and what we can / cannot do. We need certain specific informaQon to move forward with a case. We can definitely work with you to make sure your complaint is filed correctly with the informaQon needed and focused on possible violaQons of the Act that we can address, and then we can begin an inquiry and see where that leads us.
Sincerely,
Lance Kinney, Ph.D., P.E. ExecuQve Director
Texas Board of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

From: Lance Kinney <Lance.Kinney@pels.texas.gov> Date: Thu, Sep 2, 2021 at 1:47 PM
Subject: RE: Mr Darwin's parQcipaQon
To: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>
CC: Michael Sims <Michael.Sims@pels.texas.gov>
Good aSernoon Mr. Kalra,
I have spoken at length with Mr. Sims concerning your situaQon and the opQons we have going forward. Below is an in-depth discussion of several items (note – it is somewhat long but we feel necessary to re-set the foundaQon for this discussion.)
The Board understands your concern with the safety of Anderson Mill Road and your home and your frustraQon with the City of Cedar Park. These are important issues and we will try to assist you in areas in which we have the legal authority and jurisdicQon to do so.
First, I feel some background on the authority, jurisdicQon, and limitaQons of the Board is needed. The Board was created by the Texas Legislature to license professional engineers and assure individuals are complying with the Texas Engineering PracQce Act (TEPA) and Board rules. This authority includes invesQgaQng allegaQons that a licensed
   Page 476 of 1607

engineer has pracQced engineering in a manner that violates TEPA or Board rules or that an unlicensed individual has engaged in the pracQce of engineering.
The Board does not necessarily have any jurisdicQon over acts taken by a professional engineer when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering (for example, a P.E.’s management style or decision making when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering).
The Board also does not have jurisdicQon over ciQes. Each city is its own sovereign jurisdicQon that has oversight of its roads, construcQon requirements, ordinances, internal operaQons, etc. The plans for buildings, roadways, and other engineering projects are not submi]ed to the Board for review or approval and we do not have any role in the acceptance, construcQon, bidding, etc. of a project. We are not involved in the oversight of a city or a city department as to what codes they adopt or implement, or the internal workings of the city itself. The Board does not have the authority to audit a City’s Public Works or Engineering Department or to conduct studies (safety studies, traffic studies, etc). Those are ma]ers under the jurisdicQon of the city itself – the city council, mayor, or whatever structure the city leadership takes. Again, we are charged with the licensure of individual engineers and engineering firms and compliance as it relates directly to the TEPA.
One addiQonal note – as discussed previously, the Board also is not in the posiQon to advocate for or against individuals in disagreements with a city. The Board can invesQgate complaints, but has no role in an individual acQons against a city.
From reviewing the informaQon you have provided, it is clear that you have concerns about the decision making coming out of the City of Cedar Park’s Engineering Department as it relates to Anderson Mill and your home, and want consideraQon from the city (such as a fence or wall, etc.). While the Board can invesQgate violaQons of TEPA, the Board has no authority to ask or demand a City or City Department to take specific acQons. We are not charged with overseeing projects such as roadways – that is the purview of the jurisdicQon itself. For example – for a Texas highway, TXDOT is responsible for the roadway, its design, construcQon, and maintenance. The same framework is in place for roadways within a city – Cedar Park is responsible for its porQon of this road. The Board only has limited jurisdicQon related to municipaliQes. Our jurisdicQon over a city is to ensure that they hire engineers to do engineering work, which the City of Cedar Park seems to have done in this project. The Board does not have the authority to undertake many of the addiQonal tasks of which you are asking (conducQng independent traffic studies or a safety study). This would be something that the city would do, if required by a code, ordinance, law, or other guidance, or if they agree to do so independently.
Based on the informaQon you have provided to date, we also do not see that SecQon 1001.407 of the Texas Engineering PracQce Act has been violated. The law requires that a municipality engage a P.E. for engineering plans, specificaQons, and esQmates. This means engineering plans, engineering specificaQons, and engineering esQmates. It does not call out any parQcular kind of plan or esQmate, such as a safety plan or analysis. It simply means that any engineering work that is done must be done by a P.E. It seems that they have met this requirement through Binkley Barfield or internal engineering staff. As a note, engineering esQmates are generally considered to be the engineering porQon of a materials esQmate, such as quanQQes and grades / specificaQons of different construcQon materials for a project. While the cosQng porQon can be done by an engineer (and if done by an engineer should be signed/sealed), in some instances, the actual pricing of materials would be done by procurement or purchasing staff as they are be]er equipped to know the contracQng and procurement side of things. Non-engineers doing a cost esQmate would not necessarily be considered a violaQon of the TEPA or Board rules.
 Page 477 of 1607

 The City indicated that they have adopted and use the standards published by AASHTO and the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual in designing roads within the city. This type of design is consistent with the Act. If you have concerns that there are specific design problems, a complaint should be filed against the design engineer, who appears to be Gregory Calkins, P.E.
In your communicaQons you also discuss the lack of a sound barrier. For this to be a potenQal violaQon, you would need to provide a local or state code or ordinance that is being violated by not construcQng a sound barrier. The Board understands that you believe such a barrier is warranted, but the lack of the barrier would need to be Qed back to an engineer violaQng a specific local or state code or ordinance.
For the Board to move forward with invesQgaQng a complaint, you would need to provide specific instances and examples, with supporQng documentaQon, of where the design is inconsistent with generally accepted engineering pracQce, is in conflict with the AASHTO standards or the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual, or violates a Board rule. An example might be related to the safety analysis you have menQoned – while TEPA does not mandate any parQcular report or analysis be done, if a safety analysis is required by a standard or code and it was not done or done incorrectly, then it would be something that a P.E. should have done and could be a violaQon.
All of this being said, we are here to invesQgate potenQal violaQons of TEPA as set out above. If you believe that individual engineers made mistakes involving the design of the road or road expansion, then a complaint can be filed against the individual engineers that did the design. If you believe that there are design issues by an engineer at Binkley Barfield, the complaint would be against that individual. If an engineer from the City of Cedar Park made specific mistakes in the pracQce of engineering and in violaQon of TEPA, then we can invesQgate that. Please note a belief that there is a violaQon is not sufficient for the Board to take acQon; you need to indicate a specific code or ordinance that is being violated in the complaint.
One final note - outside of specific engineering issues that are related to violaQons of TEPA and under the jurisdicQon of the Board, we note that it appears many of the other concerns with the engineering department would best be addressed to the city government (city council or mayor) of Cedar Park. It is possible that your State RepresentaQve or State Senator could assist with your issues with the city.
I know this is a long email with a lot of informaQon, but please understand that there are restricQons on the jurisdicQon of the Board and what we can / cannot do. We need certain specific informaQon to move forward with a case. We can definitely work with you to make sure your complaint is filed correctly with the informaQon needed and focused on possible violaQons of the Act that we can address, and then we can begin an inquiry and see where that leads us.
Sincerely,
Lance Kinney, Ph.D., P.E.

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

From: Lance Kinney <Lance.Kinney@pels.texas.gov> Date: Thu, Sep 2, 2021 at 1:47 PM
Subject: RE: Mr Darwin's parQcipaQon
To: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>
CC: Michael Sims <Michael.Sims@pels.texas.gov>
Good aSernoon Mr. Kalra,
I have spoken at length with Mr. Sims concerning your situaQon and the opQons we have going forward. Below is an in-depth discussion of several items (note – it is somewhat long but we feel necessary to re-set the foundaQon for this discussion.)
The Board understands your concern with the safety of Anderson Mill Road and your home and your frustraQon with the City of Cedar Park. These are important issues and we will try to assist you in areas in which we have the legal authority and jurisdicQon to do so.
First, I feel some background on the authority, jurisdicQon, and limitaQons of the Board is needed. The Board was created by the Texas Legislature to license professional engineers and assure individuals are complying with the Texas Engineering PracQce Act (TEPA) and Board rules. This authority includes invesQgaQng allegaQons that a licensed engineer has pracQced engineering in a manner that violates TEPA or Board rules or that an unlicensed individual has
   Page 500 of 1607

engaged in the pracQce of engineering.
 The Board does not necessarily have any jurisdicQon over acts taken by a professional engineer when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering (for example, a P.E.’s management style or decision making when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering).
The Board also does not have jurisdicQon over ciQes. Each city is its own sovereign jurisdicQon that has oversight of its roads, construcQon requirements, ordinances, internal operaQons, etc. The plans for buildings, roadways, and other engineering projects are not submi]ed to the Board for review or approval and we do not have any role in the acceptance, construcQon, bidding, etc. of a project. We are not involved in the oversight of a city or a city department as to what codes they adopt or implement, or the internal workings of the city itself. The Board does not have the authority to audit a City’s Public Works or Engineering Department or to conduct studies (safety studies, traffic studies, etc). Those are ma]ers under the jurisdicQon of the city itself – the city council, mayor, or whatever structure the city leadership takes. Again, we are charged with the licensure of individual engineers and engineering firms and compliance as it relates directly to the TEPA.
One addiQonal note – as discussed previously, the Board also is not in the posiQon to advocate for or against individuals in disagreements with a city. The Board can invesQgate complaints, but has no role in an individual acQons against a city.
From reviewing the informaQon you have provided, it is clear that you have concerns about the decision making coming out of the City of Cedar Park’s Engineering Department as it relates to Anderson Mill and your home, and want consideraQon from the city (such as a fence or wall, etc.). While the Board can invesQgate violaQons of TEPA, the Board has no authority to ask or demand a City or City Department to take specific acQons. We are not charged with overseeing projects such as roadways – that is the purview of the jurisdicQon itself. For example – for a Texas highway, TXDOT is responsible for the roadway, its design, construcQon, and maintenance. The same framework is in place for roadways within a city – Cedar Park is responsible for its porQon of this road. The Board only has limited jurisdicQon related to municipaliQes. Our jurisdicQon over a city is to ensure that they hire engineers to do engineering work, which the City of Cedar Park seems to have done in this project. The Board does not have the authority to undertake many of the addiQonal tasks of which you are asking (conducQng independent traffic studies or a safety study). This would be something that the city would do, if required by a code, ordinance, law, or other guidance, or if they agree to do so independently.
Based on the informaQon you have provided to date, we also do not see that SecQon 1001.407 of the Texas Engineering PracQce Act has been violated. The law requires that a municipality engage a P.E. for engineering plans, specificaQons, and esQmates. This means engineering plans, engineering specificaQons, and engineering esQmates. It does not call out any parQcular kind of plan or esQmate, such as a safety plan or analysis. It simply means that any engineering work that is done must be done by a P.E. It seems that they have met this requirement through Binkley Barfield or internal engineering staff. As a note, engineering esQmates are generally considered to be the engineering porQon of a materials esQmate, such as quanQQes and grades / specificaQons of different construcQon materials for a project. While the cosQng porQon can be done by an engineer (and if done by an engineer should be signed/sealed), in some instances, the actual pricing of materials would be done by procurement or purchasing staff as they are be]er equipped to know the contracQng and procurement side of things. Non-engineers doing a cost esQmate would not necessarily be considered a violaQon of the TEPA or Board rules.
Page 501 of 1607

 The City indicated that they have adopted and use the standards published by AASHTO and the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual in designing roads within the city. This type of design is consistent with the Act. If you have concerns that there are specific design problems, a complaint should be filed against the design engineer, who appears to be Gregory Calkins, P.E.
In your communicaQons you also discuss the lack of a sound barrier. For this to be a potenQal violaQon, you would need to provide a local or state code or ordinance that is being violated by not construcQng a sound barrier. The Board understands that you believe such a barrier is warranted, but the lack of the barrier would need to be Qed back to an engineer violaQng a specific local or state code or ordinance.
For the Board to move forward with invesQgaQng a complaint, you would need to provide specific instances and examples, with supporQng documentaQon, of where the design is inconsistent with generally accepted engineering pracQce, is in conflict with the AASHTO standards or the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual, or violates a Board rule. An example might be related to the safety analysis you have menQoned – while TEPA does not mandate any parQcular report or analysis be done, if a safety analysis is required by a standard or code and it was not done or done incorrectly, then it would be something that a P.E. should have done and could be a violaQon.
All of this being said, we are here to invesQgate potenQal violaQons of TEPA as set out above. If you believe that individual engineers made mistakes involving the design of the road or road expansion, then a complaint can be filed against the individual engineers that did the design. If you believe that there are design issues by an engineer at Binkley Barfield, the complaint would be against that individual. If an engineer from the City of Cedar Park made specific mistakes in the pracQce of engineering and in violaQon of TEPA, then we can invesQgate that. Please note a belief that there is a violaQon is not sufficient for the Board to take acQon; you need to indicate a specific code or ordinance that is being violated in the complaint.
One final note - outside of specific engineering issues that are related to violaQons of TEPA and under the jurisdicQon of the Board, we note that it appears many of the other concerns with the engineering department would best be addressed to the city government (city council or mayor) of Cedar Park. It is possible that your State RepresentaQve or State Senator could assist with your issues with the city.
I know this is a long email with a lot of informaQon, but please understand that there are restricQons on the jurisdicQon of the Board and what we can / cannot do. We need certain specific informaQon to move forward with a case. We can definitely work with you to make sure your complaint is filed correctly with the informaQon needed and focused on possible violaQons of the Act that we can address, and then we can begin an inquiry and see where that leads us.
Sincerely,
Lance Kinney, Ph.D., P.E. ExecuQve Director
Page 502 of 1607

1917 S. Interstate 35, AusQn, TX 78741-3702

From: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Lance Kinney <Lance.Kinney@pels.texas.gov> Date: Thu, Sep 2, 2021 at 1:47 PM
Subject: RE: Mr Darwin's parQcipaQon
To: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>
CC: Michael Sims <Michael.Sims@pels.texas.gov>
Good aSernoon Mr. Kalra,
I have spoken at length with Mr. Sims concerning your situaQon and the opQons we have going forward. Below is an in-depth discussion of several items (note – it is somewhat long but we feel necessary to re-set the foundaQon for this discussion.)
The Board understands your concern with the safety of Anderson Mill Road and your home and your frustraQon with the City of Cedar Park. These are important issues and we will try to assist you in areas in which we have the legal authority and jurisdicQon to do so.
First, I feel some background on the authority, jurisdicQon, and limitaQons of the Board is needed. The Board was created by the Texas Legislature to license professional engineers and assure individuals are complying with the Texas Engineering PracQce Act (TEPA) and Board rules. This authority includes invesQgaQng allegaQons that a licensed engineer has pracQced engineering in a manner that violates TEPA or Board rules or that an unlicensed individual has engaged in the pracQce of engineering.
   Page 524 of 1607

 The Board does not necessarily have any jurisdicQon over acts taken by a professional engineer when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering (for example, a P.E.’s management style or decision making when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering).
The Board also does not have jurisdicQon over ciQes. Each city is its own sovereign jurisdicQon that has oversight of its roads, construcQon requirements, ordinances, internal operaQons, etc. The plans for buildings, roadways, and other engineering projects are not submi]ed to the Board for review or approval and we do not have any role in the acceptance, construcQon, bidding, etc. of a project. We are not involved in the oversight of a city or a city department as to what codes they adopt or implement, or the internal workings of the city itself. The Board does not have the authority to audit a City’s Public Works or Engineering Department or to conduct studies (safety studies, traffic studies, etc). Those are ma]ers under the jurisdicQon of the city itself – the city council, mayor, or whatever structure the city leadership takes. Again, we are charged with the licensure of individual engineers and engineering firms and compliance as it relates directly to the TEPA.
One addiQonal note – as discussed previously, the Board also is not in the posiQon to advocate for or against individuals in disagreements with a city. The Board can invesQgate complaints, but has no role in an individual acQons against a city.
From reviewing the informaQon you have provided, it is clear that you have concerns about the decision making coming out of the City of Cedar Park’s Engineering Department as it relates to Anderson Mill and your home, and want consideraQon from the city (such as a fence or wall, etc.). While the Board can invesQgate violaQons of TEPA, the Board has no authority to ask or demand a City or City Department to take specific acQons. We are not charged with overseeing projects such as roadways – that is the purview of the jurisdicQon itself. For example – for a Texas highway, TXDOT is responsible for the roadway, its design, construcQon, and maintenance. The same framework is in place for roadways within a city – Cedar Park is responsible for its porQon of this road. The Board only has limited jurisdicQon related to municipaliQes. Our jurisdicQon over a city is to ensure that they hire engineers to do engineering work, which the City of Cedar Park seems to have done in this project. The Board does not have the authority to undertake many of the addiQonal tasks of which you are asking (conducQng independent traffic studies or a safety study). This would be something that the city would do, if required by a code, ordinance, law, or other guidance, or if they agree to do so independently.
Based on the informaQon you have provided to date, we also do not see that SecQon 1001.407 of the Texas Engineering PracQce Act has been violated. The law requires that a municipality engage a P.E. for engineering plans, specificaQons, and esQmates. This means engineering plans, engineering specificaQons, and engineering esQmates. It does not call out any parQcular kind of plan or esQmate, such as a safety plan or analysis. It simply means that any engineering work that is done must be done by a P.E. It seems that they have met this requirement through Binkley Barfield or internal engineering staff. As a note, engineering esQmates are generally considered to be the engineering porQon of a materials esQmate, such as quanQQes and grades / specificaQons of different construcQon materials for a project. While the cosQng porQon can be done by an engineer (and if done by an engineer should be signed/sealed), in some instances, the actual pricing of materials would be done by procurement or purchasing staff as they are be]er equipped to know the contracQng and procurement side of things. Non-engineers doing a cost esQmate would not necessarily be considered a violaQon of the TEPA or Board rules.
The City indicated that they have adopted and use the standards published by AASHTO and the City of AusQn
Page 525 of 1607

TransportaQon Manual in designing roads within the city. This type of design is consistent with the Act. If you have concerns that there are specific design problems, a complaint should be filed against the design engineer, who appears to be Gregory Calkins, P.E.
In your communicaQons you also discuss the lack of a sound barrier. For this to be a potenQal violaQon, you would need to provide a local or state code or ordinance that is being violated by not construcQng a sound barrier. The Board understands that you believe such a barrier is warranted, but the lack of the barrier would need to be Qed back to an engineer violaQng a specific local or state code or ordinance.
For the Board to move forward with invesQgaQng a complaint, you would need to provide specific instances and examples, with supporQng documentaQon, of where the design is inconsistent with generally accepted engineering pracQce, is in conflict with the AASHTO standards or the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual, or violates a Board rule. An example might be related to the safety analysis you have menQoned – while TEPA does not mandate any parQcular report or analysis be done, if a safety analysis is required by a standard or code and it was not done or done incorrectly, then it would be something that a P.E. should have done and could be a violaQon.
All of this being said, we are here to invesQgate potenQal violaQons of TEPA as set out above. If you believe that individual engineers made mistakes involving the design of the road or road expansion, then a complaint can be filed against the individual engineers that did the design. If you believe that there are design issues by an engineer at Binkley Barfield, the complaint would be against that individual. If an engineer from the City of Cedar Park made specific mistakes in the pracQce of engineering and in violaQon of TEPA, then we can invesQgate that. Please note a belief that there is a violaQon is not sufficient for the Board to take acQon; you need to indicate a specific code or ordinance that is being violated in the complaint.
One final note - outside of specific engineering issues that are related to violaQons of TEPA and under the jurisdicQon of the Board, we note that it appears many of the other concerns with the engineering department would best be addressed to the city government (city council or mayor) of Cedar Park. It is possible that your State RepresentaQve or State Senator could assist with your issues with the city.
I know this is a long email with a lot of informaQon, but please understand that there are restricQons on the jurisdicQon of the Board and what we can / cannot do. We need certain specific informaQon to move forward with a case. We can definitely work with you to make sure your complaint is filed correctly with the informaQon needed and focused on possible violaQons of the Act that we can address, and then we can begin an inquiry and see where that leads us.
Sincerely,

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

From: Lance Kinney <Lance.Kinney@pels.texas.gov> Date: Thu, Sep 2, 2021 at 1:47 PM
Subject: RE: Mr Darwin's parQcipaQon
To: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>
CC: Michael Sims <Michael.Sims@pels.texas.gov>
Good aSernoon Mr. Kalra,
I have spoken at length with Mr. Sims concerning your situaQon and the opQons we have going forward. Below is an in-depth discussion of several items (note – it is somewhat long but we feel necessary to re-set the foundaQon for this discussion.)
The Board understands your concern with the safety of Anderson Mill Road and your home and your frustraQon with the City of Cedar Park. These are important issues and we will try to assist you in areas in which we have the legal authority and jurisdicQon to do so.
First, I feel some background on the authority, jurisdicQon, and limitaQons of the Board is needed. The Board was created by the Texas Legislature to license professional engineers and assure individuals are complying with the Texas Engineering PracQce Act (TEPA) and Board rules. This authority includes invesQgaQng allegaQons that a licensed engineer has pracQced engineering in a manner that violates TEPA or Board rules or that an unlicensed individual has engaged in the pracQce of engineering.
   Page 548 of 1607

 The Board does not necessarily have any jurisdicQon over acts taken by a professional engineer when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering (for example, a P.E.’s management style or decision making when he or she is not engaged in the pracQce of engineering).
The Board also does not have jurisdicQon over ciQes. Each city is its own sovereign jurisdicQon that has oversight of its roads, construcQon requirements, ordinances, internal operaQons, etc. The plans for buildings, roadways, and other engineering projects are not submi]ed to the Board for review or approval and we do not have any role in the acceptance, construcQon, bidding, etc. of a project. We are not involved in the oversight of a city or a city department as to what codes they adopt or implement, or the internal workings of the city itself. The Board does not have the authority to audit a City’s Public Works or Engineering Department or to conduct studies (safety studies, traffic studies, etc). Those are ma]ers under the jurisdicQon of the city itself – the city council, mayor, or whatever structure the city leadership takes. Again, we are charged with the licensure of individual engineers and engineering firms and compliance as it relates directly to the TEPA.
One addiQonal note – as discussed previously, the Board also is not in the posiQon to advocate for or against individuals in disagreements with a city. The Board can invesQgate complaints, but has no role in an individual acQons against a city.
From reviewing the informaQon you have provided, it is clear that you have concerns about the decision making coming out of the City of Cedar Park’s Engineering Department as it relates to Anderson Mill and your home, and want consideraQon from the city (such as a fence or wall, etc.). While the Board can invesQgate violaQons of TEPA, the Board has no authority to ask or demand a City or City Department to take specific acQons. We are not charged with overseeing projects such as roadways – that is the purview of the jurisdicQon itself. For example – for a Texas highway, TXDOT is responsible for the roadway, its design, construcQon, and maintenance. The same framework is in place for roadways within a city – Cedar Park is responsible for its porQon of this road. The Board only has limited jurisdicQon related to municipaliQes. Our jurisdicQon over a city is to ensure that they hire engineers to do engineering work, which the City of Cedar Park seems to have done in this project. The Board does not have the authority to undertake many of the addiQonal tasks of which you are asking (conducQng independent traffic studies or a safety study). This would be something that the city would do, if required by a code, ordinance, law, or other guidance, or if they agree to do so independently.
Based on the informaQon you have provided to date, we also do not see that SecQon 1001.407 of the Texas Engineering PracQce Act has been violated. The law requires that a municipality engage a P.E. for engineering plans, specificaQons, and esQmates. This means engineering plans, engineering specificaQons, and engineering esQmates. It does not call out any parQcular kind of plan or esQmate, such as a safety plan or analysis. It simply means that any engineering work that is done must be done by a P.E. It seems that they have met this requirement through Binkley Barfield or internal engineering staff. As a note, engineering esQmates are generally considered to be the engineering porQon of a materials esQmate, such as quanQQes and grades / specificaQons of different construcQon materials for a project. While the cosQng porQon can be done by an engineer (and if done by an engineer should be signed/sealed), in some instances, the actual pricing of materials would be done by procurement or purchasing staff as they are be]er equipped to know the contracQng and procurement side of things. Non-engineers doing a cost esQmate would not necessarily be considered a violaQon of the TEPA or Board rules.
The City indicated that they have adopted and use the standards published by AASHTO and the City of AusQn
Page 549 of 1607

TransportaQon Manual in designing roads within the city. This type of design is consistent with the Act. If you have concerns that there are specific design problems, a complaint should be filed against the design engineer, who appears to be Gregory Calkins, P.E.
In your communicaQons you also discuss the lack of a sound barrier. For this to be a potenQal violaQon, you would need to provide a local or state code or ordinance that is being violated by not construcQng a sound barrier. The Board understands that you believe such a barrier is warranted, but the lack of the barrier would need to be Qed back to an engineer violaQng a specific local or state code or ordinance.
For the Board to move forward with invesQgaQng a complaint, you would need to provide specific instances and examples, with supporQng documentaQon, of where the design is inconsistent with generally accepted engineering pracQce, is in conflict with the AASHTO standards or the City of AusQn TransportaQon Manual, or violates a Board rule. An example might be related to the safety analysis you have menQoned – while TEPA does not mandate any parQcular report or analysis be done, if a safety analysis is required by a standard or code and it was not done or done incorrectly, then it would be something that a P.E. should have done and could be a violaQon.
All of this being said, we are here to invesQgate potenQal violaQons of TEPA as set out above. If you believe that individual engineers made mistakes involving the design of the road or road expansion, then a complaint can be filed against the individual engineers that did the design. If you believe that there are design issues by an engineer at Binkley Barfield, the complaint would be against that individual. If an engineer from the City of Cedar Park made specific mistakes in the pracQce of engineering and in violaQon of TEPA, then we can invesQgate that. Please note a belief that there is a violaQon is not sufficient for the Board to take acQon; you need to indicate a specific code or ordinance that is being violated in the complaint.
One final note - outside of specific engineering issues that are related to violaQons of TEPA and under the jurisdicQon of the Board, we note that it appears many of the other concerns with the engineering department would best be addressed to the city government (city council or mayor) of Cedar Park. It is possible that your State RepresentaQve or State Senator could assist with your issues with the city.
I know this is a long email with a lot of informaQon, but please understand that there are restricQons on the jurisdicQon of the Board and what we can / cannot do. We need certain specific informaQon to move forward with a case. We can definitely work with you to make sure your complaint is filed correctly with the informaQon needed and focused on possible violaQons of the Act that we can address, and then we can begin an inquiry and see where that leads us.
Sincerely,
Lance Kinney, Ph.D., P.E. ExecuQve Director

Subject: RE: Project : Anderson Mill Rd Expansion

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

From: Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> Date: Fri, Aug 3, 2018 at 11:05 AM
Subject: RE: Project : Anderson Mill Rd Expansion
To: Sandeep Kalra <sandeep.kalra@gmail.com>
Cc: Alan Green <Alan.Green@cedarparktexas.gov>
Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar
    Page 584 of 1607

            Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar

I think you are mistaken on the esQmate part.
The context of the clause is on safety, and welfare and I believe the esQmates are also associated to the safety and not to cost.
The state or a political subdivision of the state may not construct a public work involving engineering in which the public h
ealth, welfare,
or safety is involved, unless:
(1) th
e engineering plans, specifications, and estimates have been prepared by an engineer; and (2) the engineering construction is to be performed under the direct supervision of an engineer

I think you are mistaken on the esQmate part.
The context of the clause is on safety, and welfare and I believe the esQmates are also associated to the safety and not to cost.
The state or a political subdivision of the state may not construct a public work involving engineering in which the public h
ealth, welfare,
or safety is involved, unless:
(1) th
e engineering plans, specifications, and estimates have been prepared by an engineer; and (2) the engineering construction is to be performed under the direct supervision of an engineer

On Wed, Aug 1, 2018 at 11:27 AM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
Alan will be happy to meet you tomorrow morning at 9am to measure these distances as was discussed in his earlier email.

       Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and
    Page 625 of 1607

           verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

          Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

          Sandeep,

We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

          Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
     Page 731 of 1607

          The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.

Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

From: Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> Date: Fri, Aug 3, 2018 at 11:05 AM

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the
    Page 768 of 1607

        drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the

The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
         Page 805 of 1607

           Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
Alan will be happy to meet you tomorrow morning at 9am to measure these distances as was discussed in his earlier email.

On Mon, Jul 30, 2018 at 12:08 PM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote:
Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside
   Page 809 of 1607

Tuesday, December 6, 2022 at 17:06:29 Central Standard Time
                northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
