Cc: anderson.mill.road@gmail.com; dkalra111 <dkalra111@gmail.com>; Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov>; leann.quinn@cedarparktexas.gov; mayor.vanarsdale@cedarparktexas.gov; Jody Barr <Jody.Barr@kxan.com>; Erica Gonzales <erica.gonzales@goodwintx.com>; KrisQ Estes <krisQ.estes@goodwintx.com>
Subject: Re: NoQce of withdrawal of permission to touch fence or change anything
We will appreciate if an email acknowledgment is made by the recipient.
-- Decision --
We reject the current fence offer made by the city of cedar park, thus the restric^ons to enter our property s^ll exists.
I and my wife(called "we") has collecQvely decided that the Anderson mill road expansion project is not safe for us and our family, friends and for any resident around our property. Our decision is based on the ra^onale that is posted towards the end of this email. As with the situaQon at hand, we see absolutely no benefits in accepQng the deal of just a higher (addiQonal 2 S) wood fence to what we have now.
We see this moment as an opportunity to either get a wriQng a worked out plan for our safety from HOA(The HOA of bu]ercup creek, Cedar Park, TX) and/or City (The city of cedar park) or else to tell them (to HOA and/or City) what our next acQon will be in case they fail to provide us with the basic safety, security, and peace of mind.
We also see this moment to tell what we see wrong in this project and our frustraQon, sadness, and loss of trust for the engineers, City, and/or HOA involved directly or indirectly with the execuQon of this project.
-- What we will accept --
we will accept one of the 4 opQons/plans given below.
             Page 1400 of 1607

    [ Plan 1 ] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City does the complete calculaQon for the worst case for the whole project and guarantee us in wriQng that the risks are less than 1% for anyone standing on my property line or the sidewalk next to it (at any place).
[ Plan 2] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City and/or the HOA undertakes in wriQng a non-revokable, and with no statuary-limits undertaking that any accidents will be compensated with more than $50m / per person involved.
[ Plan 3] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City makes for us a barrier of 3 S at the roadside.
[ Plan 4] This is the open-ended plan. If HOA and/or City have anything be]er to offer and also guaranteed to be safe and secure (must be backed by calculaQons and previous data of similar deployments) then we are also open to considering them. All the documents must be developed by licensed engineers and must be backed by 2 addiQonal PE engineers appointed by City. In this case, we will accept the 8 S wooden fence only aSer making sure that the plan is safe.
Note: The deadline for the agreement is either "End of the current project" or "The day when the lane next to our property is ready for the public to use". Whichever comes first.
-- otherwise, what we plan on doing next --
We will build our own wall. The size(15S) and material(concrete or stone) were already published by us in our recommendaQons when we met the city for the first Qme in May 2017. The concerns (in form of PDF, called concerns.pdf) were given to them as a resident who has been facing the challenges out from this development since Jan 2017. A copy of it is a]ached. The readings will be from the outside of the property (i.e. at walkway level). We will not provide access to anyone from HOA or city to enter our property for any inspecQon.
We may possibly go to the law of the state and TBPE and ask for our safety and to showcase the wrongdoings of state and the licensed engineers.
-- RaQonale --
Property sits at a point where a potenQal 40000 lbs to 80,000 lbs 18 wheelers are allowed northbound @ 40 mph. Part of the project is developed on
simple specula^ons such as all drivers are slow, no one will overtake, no one will be drunk at all ^me etc). There are no checks and balances if they turn right or just park right next to the property. No street lights next to the
walkway. No red-lights to make the traffic stop or slow down. No Barrier to protect our safety from 18 wheelers. No CalculaQons based on models developed using mathemaQcs, science and past experiences from similar situaQons. No Noise control. No trees. No polluQon checks. No risk analysis. The city is not even able to find 20 other properQes in the similar situaQon in whole
 Page 1401 of 1607

Tuesday, December 6, 2022 at 17:12:52 Central Standard Time
     Cedar Park. This walkway is the most unsafe journey that my family will be taking from my own house to the backyard land that I leS as an easement for uQlity lines. 100% risk, and for rewards it is just an addi^onal 2 g high wood fence?. The unprotected walkway will be used by kids going to school, bicycles, joggers and others pedestrians. Walkway to deer creek elementary was merely 5-6 S wide in few places while I took the journey to elementary school.
My front yard is now almost unusable with just 6 to 8 S away from the road with no protecQon. 400+ vehicles per day make it equivalent of highway (Ref: Greenbook, AASHTO, 2001). With the distance of road as close as 6 S. to our property line, we do not feel safe. See addendum on Measurements for the readings.
Add-ons RaQonales: [The ironic ones]
- By the engineer's argument: The drivers on this road are blind enough to not see the 3-4 S barrier and need a line of sight else they will crash in, but the drivers surprisingly have 20/20 vision when a 3 to 4 S high kid is on the same walkway.
- Texas ranks 11th (out of 50 states) in drunk driving accidents (2017 data). Yet the engineers never envision a single drunk driver of the car, or the truck hiÄng the curb or side of the road.
- The engineers can promise (we have 10+ residents as the witness and possibly a recording audio of meeQng with details) that they will give at least 3 S barrier and retenQon wall to all properQes, and they can simply walk back their own words because they think no one will quesQon them.
- The city and HOA would not accept different looking boundary walls/fences unQl they have to offer it and someone can say no and end up with different wall/fence than others. Looks like the rules are just for the residents and not for city and HOA.
- Licensed PE Engineers are asked for engineering documents with reference to exact secQons per TBPE documents, and they get back with Business documents and cost calculaQons.
- The city will ask for concerns from those who will face the music 7 x 24 x 365 (i.e. the residents), but mute itself into accepQng whatever the engineers suggest who are running this project as their backyard project.
- The city failed to persuade AusQn-City to give part of the land that AusQn uses for birds, so Cedar Park picked up the fight with local residents because they can do so.
-- The mindset of the City and HOA is worrisome here:
They have just one line of thought: If one property owner gets a wall or different barrier because of the valid safety concerns then others may ask for it and the job of denying them will be hard, so let us not give it to the resident with reasons.
-- Addendum: Measurements (+- 0.2 S margin )--
Readings are taken on my property (from front to back). All readings were taken from the edge of curb to property line.
 Page 1402 of 1607

    Front Yard: Min distance to the road from my property line is 6 S. Max distance is 9 S from the property line.
From fence start to the point the right lane mee^ng point: Min is 9 S, and the Max distance is at 10 S from the property line.
Back Yard: Min is 11 S. Farthest is 20+ S.
Thanks,
Sandeep Kalra & Deepshikha Kalra
201 Gaspar Bend, Cedar Park, TX 78613 Dated : 09/24/2018

We will appreciate if an email acknowledgment is made by the recipient. -- Decision --
We reject the current fence offer made by the city of cedar park, thus the restric^ons to enter our property s^ll exists.
I and my wife(called "we") has collecQvely decided that the Anderson mill road expansion project is not safe for us and our family, friends and for any resident around our property. Our decision is based on the ra^onale that is posted towards the end of this email. As with the situaQon at hand, we see absolutely no benefits in accepQng the deal of just a higher (addiQonal 2 S) wood fence to what we have now.
We see this moment as an opportunity to either get a wriQng a worked out plan for our safety from HOA(The HOA of bu]ercup creek, Cedar Park, TX) and/or City (The city of cedar park) or else to tell them (to HOA and/or City) what our next acQon will be in case they fail to provide us with the basic safety, security, and peace of mind.
We also see this moment to tell what we see wrong in this project and our frustraQon, sadness, and loss of trust for the engineers, City, and/or HOA involved directly or indirectly with the execuQon of this project.
-- What we will accept --
we will accept one of the 4 opQons/plans given below.
[ Plan 1 ] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City does the complete calculaQon for the worst case for the whole project and guarantee us in wriQng that the risks are less than 1% for anyone standing on my property line or the sidewalk next to it (at any place).
  [ Plan 2] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City and/or the HOA
 Page 1416 of 1607

    undertakes in wriQng a non-revokable, and with no statuary-limits undertaking that any accidents will be compensated with more than $50m / per person involved.
[ Plan 3] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City makes for us a barrier of 3 S at the roadside.
[ Plan 4] This is the open-ended plan. If HOA and/or City have anything be]er to offer and also guaranteed to be safe and secure (must be backed by calculaQons and previous data of similar deployments) then we are also open to considering them. All the documents must be developed by licensed engineers and must be backed by 2 addiQonal PE engineers appointed by City. In this case, we will accept the 8 S wooden fence only aSer making sure that the plan is safe.
Note: The deadline for the agreement is either "End of the current project" or "The day when the lane next to our property is ready for the public to use". Whichever comes first.
-- otherwise, what we plan on doing next --
We will build our own wall. The size(15S) and material(concrete or stone) were already published by us in our recommendaQons when we met the city for the first Qme in May 2017. The concerns (in form of PDF, called concerns.pdf) were given to them as a resident who has been facing the challenges out from this development since Jan 2017. A copy of it is a]ached. The readings will be from the outside of the property (i.e. at walkway level). We will not provide access to anyone from HOA or city to enter our property for any inspecQon.
We may possibly go to the law of the state and TBPE and ask for our safety and to showcase the wrongdoings of state and the licensed engineers.
-- RaQonale --
Property sits at a point where a potenQal 40000 lbs to 80,000 lbs 18 wheelers are allowed northbound @ 40 mph. Part of the project is developed on
simple specula^ons such as all drivers are slow, no one will overtake, no one will be drunk at all ^me etc). There are no checks and balances if they turn right or just park right next to the property. No street lights next to the
walkway. No red-lights to make the traffic stop or slow down. No Barrier to protect our safety from 18 wheelers. No CalculaQons based on models developed
 Page 1417 of 1607

Tuesday, December 6, 2022 at 17:13:02 Central Standard Time
     using mathemaQcs, science and past experiences from similar situaQons. No Noise control. No trees. No polluQon checks. No risk analysis. The city is not even able to find 20 other properQes in the similar situaQon in whole Cedar Park. This walkway is the most unsafe journey that my family will be taking from my own house to the backyard land that I leS as an easement for uQlity lines. 100% risk, and for rewards it is just an addi^onal 2 g high wood fence?. The unprotected walkway will be used by kids going to school, bicycles, joggers and others pedestrians. Walkway to deer creek elementary was merely 5-6 S wide in few places while I took the journey to elementary school.
My front yard is now almost unusable with just 6 to 8 S away from the road with no protecQon. 400+ vehicles per day make it equivalent of highway (Ref: Greenbook, AASHTO, 2001). With the distance of road as close as 6 S. to our property line, we do not feel safe. See addendum on Measurements for the readings.
Add-ons RaQonales: [The ironic ones]
- By the engineer's argument: The drivers on this road are blind enough to not see the 3-4 S barrier and need a line of sight else they will crash in, but the drivers surprisingly have 20/20 vision when a 3 to 4 S high kid is on the same walkway.
- Texas ranks 11th (out of 50 states) in drunk driving accidents (2017 data). Yet the engineers never envision a single drunk driver of the car, or the truck hiÄng the curb or side of the road.
- The engineers can promise (we have 10+ residents as the witness and possibly a recording audio of meeQng with details) that they will give at least 3 S barrier and retenQon wall to all properQes, and they can simply walk back their own words because they think no one will quesQon them.
- The city and HOA would not accept different looking boundary walls/fences unQl they have to offer it and someone can say no and end up with different wall/fence than others. Looks like the rules are just for the residents and not for city and HOA.
- Licensed PE Engineers are asked for engineering documents with reference to exact secQons per TBPE documents, and they get back with Business documents and cost calculaQons.
- The city will ask for concerns from those who will face the music 7 x 24 x 365 (i.e. the residents), but mute itself into accepQng whatever the engineers suggest who are running this project as their backyard project.
- The city failed to persuade AusQn-City to give part of the land that AusQn uses for birds, so Cedar Park picked up the fight with local residents because they can do so.
 Page 1418 of 1607

    -- The mindset of the City and HOA is worrisome here:
They have just one line of thought: If one property owner gets a wall or different barrier because of the valid safety concerns then others may ask for it and the job of denying them will be hard, so let us not give it to the resident with reasons.
-- Addendum: Measurements (+- 0.2 S margin )--
Readings are taken on my property (from front to back). All readings were taken from the edge of curb to property line.
Front Yard: Min distance to the road from my property line is 6 S. Max distance is 9 S from the property line.
From fence start to the point the right lane mee^ng point: Min is 9 S, and the Max distance is at 10 S from the property line.
Back Yard: Min is 11 S. Farthest is 20+ S.
Thanks,
Sandeep Kalra & Deepshikha Kalra

Subject: Re: NoQce of withdrawal of permission to touch fence or change anything
We will appreciate if an email acknowledgment is made by the recipient.
-- Decision --
We reject the current fence offer made by the city of cedar park, thus the restric^ons to enter our property s^ll exists.
               Page 1435 of 1607

   I and my wife(called "we") has collecQvely decided that the Anderson mill road expansion project is not safe for us and our family, friends and for any resident around our property. Our decision is based on the ra^onale that is posted towards the end of this email. As with the situaQon at hand, we see absolutely no benefits in accepQng the deal of just a higher (addiQonal 2 S) wood fence to what we have now.
We see this moment as an opportunity to either get a wriQng a worked out plan for our safety from HOA(The HOA of bu]ercup creek, Cedar Park, TX) and/or City (The city of cedar park) or else to tell them (to HOA and/or City) what our next acQon will be in case they fail to provide us with the basic safety, security, and peace of mind.
We also see this moment to tell what we see wrong in this project and our frustraQon, sadness, and loss of trust for the engineers, City, and/or HOA involved directly or indirectly with the execuQon of this project.
-- What we will accept --
we will accept one of the 4 opQons/plans given below.
[ Plan 1 ] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City does the complete calculaQon for the worst case for the whole project and guarantee us in wriQng that the risks are less than 1% for anyone standing on my property line or the sidewalk next to it (at any place).
[ Plan 2] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City and/or the HOA undertakes in wriQng a non- revokable, and with no statuary-limits undertaking that any accidents will be compensated with more than $50m / per person involved.
[ Plan 3] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City makes for us a barrier of 3 S at the roadside.
[ Plan 4] This is the open-ended plan. If HOA and/or City have anything be]er to offer and also guaranteed to be safe and secure (must be backed by calculaQons and previous data of similar deployments) then we are also open to considering them. All the documents must be developed by licensed engineers and must be backed by 2 addiQonal PE engineers appointed by City. In this case, we will accept the 8 S wooden fence only aSer making sure that the plan is safe.
Note: The deadline for the agreement is either "End of the current project" or "The day when the lane next to our property is ready for the public to use". Whichever comes first.
-- otherwise, what we plan on doing next --
We will build our own wall. The size(15S) and material(concrete or stone) were already published by us in
 Page 1436 of 1607

Tuesday, December 6, 2022 at 17:13:14 Central Standard Time
    our recommendaQons when we met the city for the first Qme in May 2017. The concerns (in form of PDF, called concerns.pdf) were given to them as a resident who has been facing the challenges out from this development since Jan 2017. A copy of it is a]ached. The readings will be from the outside of the property (i.e. at walkway level). We will not provide access to anyone from HOA or city to enter our property for any inspecQon.
We may possibly go to the law of the state and TBPE and ask for our safety and to showcase the wrongdoings of state and the licensed engineers.
-- RaQonale --
Property sits at a point where a potenQal 40000 lbs to 80,000 lbs 18 wheelers are allowed northbound @ 40 mph. Part of the project is developed on simple specula^ons such as all drivers are slow, no one will overtake, no one will be drunk at all ^me etc). There are no checks and balances if they turn right or just park right next to the property. No street lights next to the walkway. No red-lights to make the traffic stop or slow down. No Barrier to protect our safety from 18 wheelers. No CalculaQons based on models developed using mathemaQcs, science and past experiences from similar situaQons. No Noise
control. No trees. No polluQon checks. No risk analysis. The city is not even able to find 20 other properQes in the similar situaQon in whole Cedar Park. This walkway is the most unsafe journey that my family will be taking from my own house to the backyard land that I leS as an easement for uQlity lines. 100% risk, and for rewards it is just an addi^onal 2 g high wood fence?. The unprotected walkway will be used by kids going to school, bicycles, joggers and others pedestrians. Walkway to deer creek elementary was merely 5-6 S wide in few places while I took the journey to elementary school.
My front yard is now almost unusable with just 6 to 8 S away from the road with no protecQon. 400+ vehicles per day make it equivalent of highway (Ref: Greenbook, AASHTO, 2001). With the distance of road as close as 6 S. to our property line, we do not feel safe. See addendum on Measurements for the readings.
Add-ons RaQonales: [The ironic ones]
- By the engineer's argument: The drivers on this road are blind enough to not see the 3-4 S barrier and need a line of sight else they will crash in, but the drivers surprisingly have 20/20 vision when a 3 to 4 S high kid is on the same walkway.
- Texas ranks 11th (out of 50 states) in drunk driving accidents (2017 data). Yet the engineers never envision a single drunk driver of the car, or the truck hiÄng the curb or side of the road.
- The engineers can promise (we have 10+ residents as the witness and possibly a recording audio of meeQng with details) that they will give at least 3 S barrier and retenQon wall to all properQes, and they can simply walk back their own words because they think no one will quesQon them.
- The city and HOA would not accept different looking boundary walls/fences unQl they have to offer it and someone can say no and end up with different wall/fence than others. Looks like the rules are just for the residents and not for city and HOA.
- Licensed PE Engineers are asked for engineering documents with reference to exact secQons per TBPE documents, and they get back with Business documents and cost calculaQons.
 Page 1437 of 1607

   - The city will ask for concerns from those who will face the music 7 x 24 x 365 (i.e. the residents), but mute itself into accepQng whatever the engineers suggest who are running this project as their backyard project.
- The city failed to persuade AusQn-City to give part of the land that AusQn uses for birds, so Cedar Park picked up the fight with local residents because they can do so.
-- The mindset of the City and HOA is worrisome here:
They have just one line of thought: If one property owner gets a wall or different barrier because of the valid safety concerns then others may ask for it and the job of denying them will be hard, so let us not give it to the resident with reasons.
-- Addendum: Measurements (+- 0.2 S margin )--
Readings are taken on my property (from front to back). All readings were taken from the edge of curb to property line.
Front Yard: Min distance to the road from my property line is 6 S. Max distance is 9 S from the property line.
From fence start to the point the right lane mee^ng point: Min is 9 S, and the Max distance is at 10 S from the property line.
Back Yard: Min is 11 S. Farthest is 20+ S.
Thanks,
Sandeep Kalra & Deepshikha Kalra

- The engineers can promise (we have 10+ residents as the witness and possibly a recording audio of meeQng with details) that they will give at least 3 S barrier and retenQon wall to all properQes, and they can simply walk back their own words because they think no one will quesQon them.
- The city and HOA would not accept different looking boundary walls/fences unQl they have to offer it and someone can say no and end up with different wall/fence than others. Looks like the rules are just for the residents and not for city and HOA.
- Licensed PE Engineers are asked for engineering documents with reference to exact secQons per TBPE documents, and they get back with Business documents and cost calculaQons.

-- Decision --
We reject the current fence offer made by the city of cedar park, thus the restric^ons to enter our property s^ll exists.
I and my wife(called "we") has collecQvely decided that the Anderson mill road
expansion project is not safe for us and our family, friends and for any resident around our property. Our decision is based on the ra^onale that is posted towards the end of this email. As with the situaQon at hand, we see absolutely no benefits in accepQng the deal of just a
higher (addiQonal 2 S) wood fence to what we have now.
We see this moment as an opportunity to either get a wriQng a worked out plan for our safety from HOA(The HOA of bu]ercup creek, Cedar Park, TX) and/or City (The city of cedar park) or else to tell them (to HOA and/or City) what our next acQon will be in case they fail to provide us with the basic safety, security, and peace of mind.
We also see this moment to tell what we see wrong in this project and our frustraQon, sadness, and loss of trust for the engineers, City, and/or HOA involved directly or indirectly with the
             Page 1451 of 1607

   execuQon of this project.
-- What we will accept --
we will accept one of the 4 opQons/plans given below.
[ Plan 1 ] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City does the complete calculaQon for the worst case for the whole project and guarantee us in wriQng that the risks are less than 1% for anyone standing on my property line or the sidewalk next to it (at any place).
[ Plan 2] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City and/or the HOA undertakes in wriQng a non-revokable, and with no statuary-limits undertaking that any accidents will be compensated with more than $50m / per person involved.
[ Plan 3] We will accept the 8 S wooden fence if the City makes for us a barrier of 3 S at the roadside.
[ Plan 4] This is the open-ended plan. If HOA and/or City have anything be]er to offer and also guaranteed to be safe and secure (must be backed by calculaQons and previous data of similar deployments) then we are also open to considering them. All the documents must be developed by licensed engineers and must be backed by 2 addiQonal PE engineers appointed by City. In this case, we will accept the 8 S wooden fence only aSer making sure that the plan is safe.
Note: The deadline for the agreement is either "End of the current project" or "The day when the lane next to our property is ready for the public to use". Whichever comes first.
-- otherwise, what we plan on doing next --
We will build our own wall. The size(15S) and material(concrete or stone) were already published by us in our recommendaQons when we met the city for the first Qme in May 2017. The concerns (in form of PDF, called concerns.pdf) were given to them as a resident who has been facing the challenges out from this development since Jan 2017. A copy of it is a]ached. The readings will be from the outside of the property (i.e. at walkway level). We will not provide access to anyone from HOA or city to enter our property for any inspecQon.
We may possibly go to the law of the state and TBPE and ask for our safety and to showcase the wrongdoings of state and the licensed engineers.

On Mon, Jul 30, 2018 at 12:08 PM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.

  I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

      On Wed, Aug 1, 2018 at 11:27 AM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

          <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin
Darwin Marchell, P.E. Director of Engineering City of Cedar Park, Texas

From: anderson millroad <anderson.mill.road@gmail.com>
Date: Fri, Aug 3, 2018 at 12:04 PM
Subject: Re: Project : Anderson Mill Rd Expansion
To: Alan Green <Alan.Green@cedarparktexas.gov>, dkalra111 <dkalra111@gmail.com>, anderson millroad <anderson.mill.road@gmail.com>, Mayor Van Arsdale <Mayor.vanarsdale@cedarparktexas.gov>, LeAnn Quinn <LeAnn.Quinn@cedarparktexas.gov>, Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov>
some stats to contemplate on:
https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/812279 https://www.burwellnebout.com/Motor-Vehicle-Accidents/18-Wheeler-Accidents/Facts-Statistics- About-18-Wheeler-Crashes-In-Texas.shtml
In the United States, there are approximately 2 million big rig trucks. Nationally, about 500,000 accidents involving 18-wheeler trucks occur yearly. Of those accidents, an estimated 5,000 result in death. Of these fatalities, 98 percent are the death of the driver or a passenger of the vehicle other than the 18-wheeler involved.
Large, heavy truck accidents cause approximately 130,000 injuries every year in the U.S.
The time of day you are driving can also make you safer on the road. According to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, most truck crashes occurred between noon and 3:00 p.m. in 2014. With a total of 17 percent of all truck crashes throughout the day and night happening between these hours, it resulted in the deaths of 622 individuals.
[Elementary school ends around this time]
https://www.isaacsandisaacs.com/truck-
           Page 1489 of 1607

 accident-lawyer/big-rig-crash-statistics
According to the Large Truck Crash Causation Study conducted for the FMCSA:
Twenty-seven percent of trucks were found to have brake problems Nineteen percent of drivers were unfamiliar with the route
10 percent of truck drivers felt under pressure
Seven percent were overly tired
Three percent experienced tire problems
Five percent were driving in an aggressive manner
One percent were ill
0.4 percent were under the influence of illegal substances 0.3 percent had been consuming alcohol

        Page 1491 of 1607

 The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.

In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

On Wed, Aug 1, 2018 at 11:27 AM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
Alan will be happy to meet you tomorrow morning at 9am to measure these distances as was discussed in his earlier email.

On Mon, Jul 30, 2018 at 12:08 PM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote:
Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin
Darwin Marchell, P.E. Director of Engineering City of Cedar Park, Texas

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the
        Page 1515 of 1607

 plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has
        Page 1526 of 1607

adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

    On Wed, Aug 1, 2018 at 11:27 AM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote: Sandeep,
Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
Alan will be happy to meet you tomorrow morning at 9am to measure these distances as was discussed in his earlier email.
Darwin

Tuesday, December 6, 2022 at 17:14:17 Central Standard Time
         wrote:
Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin
Darwin Marchell, P.E. Director of Engineering City of Cedar Park, Texas

Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.

         On Mon, Jul 30, 2018 at 12:08 PM Darwin Marchell <darwin.marchell@cedarparktexas.gov> wrote:
Mr. Kalra:
I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin
Darwin Marchell, P.E. Director of Engineering City of Cedar Park, Texas

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the
       Page 1553 of 1607

plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
 I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

some stats to contemplate on:
https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/812279 https://www.burwellnebout.com/Motor-Vehicle-Accidents/18-Wheeler-Accidents/Facts-Statistics- About-18-Wheeler-Crashes-In-Texas.shtml
In the United States, there are approximately 2 million big rig trucks. Nationally, about 500,000 accidents involving 18-wheeler trucks occur yearly. Of those accidents, an estimated 5,000 result in death. Of these fatalities, 98 percent are the death of the driver or a passenger of the vehicle other than the 18-wheeler involved.
Large, heavy truck accidents cause approximately 130,000 injuries every year in the U.S.
The time of day you are driving can also make you safer on the road. According to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, most truck crashes occurred between noon and 3:00 p.m. in 2014. With a total of 17 percent of all truck crashes throughout the day and night happening between these hours, it resulted in the deaths of 622 individuals.
[Elementary school ends around this time]
https://www.isaacsandisaacs.com/truck-
accident-lawyer/big-rig-crash-statistics
According to the Large Truck Crash Causation Study conducted for the FMCSA:
Twenty-seven percent of trucks were found to have brake problems Nineteen percent of drivers were unfamiliar with the route
10 percent of truck drivers felt under pressure
Seven percent were overly tired
             Page 1564 of 1607

 Three percent experienced tire problems
Five percent were driving in an aggressive manner
One percent were ill
0.4 percent were under the influence of illegal substances 0.3 percent had been consuming alcohol

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.

   Page 1573 of 1607

          I wanted to respond to your request for a 3 foot barrier along the edge of your property. The edge of the right turn lane pavement will be 11 feet from your property line, exceeding the desired minimum of 10 feet for a turn lane. The right turn lane will also be bound by raised curb and gu]er to provide an addiQonal barrier for traffic. Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin
Darwin Marchell, P.E. Director of Engineering City of Cedar Park, Texas

     Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
Alan will be happy to meet you tomorrow morning at 9am to measure these distances as was discussed in his earlier email.

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
        I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at
Page 1592 of 1607

your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.
Thanks, Darwin

Also, please keep in mind that the vehicles in the right turn lane will be deceleraQng to make the turn into Gaspar Bend and they will not be traveling at the same speed as those vehicles in the through lanes. The edge of the outside northbound through lane will be approximately 22 feet from your property line exceeding the 15 foot desired minimum for through lanes. There will also be a raised curb and gu]er median that will provide addiQonal separaQon to separate both the northbound and southbound traffic which increases safety in this locaQon. The City is installing a barrier further north from you since the outside northbound through lane will be less than 10 feet to some property lines and these properQes are on a curve in the roadway. Since your property is on a straight secQon of roadway and the right turn lane is a similar distance to your property as in many other locaQons, a barrier is not warranted in this locaQon. I hope this informaQon is helpful. Let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

Sandeep,
I would like to respond to your request for the “S” (specificaQons) and “E” (EsQmate) part of the PS&E for the project. We provided you with the specificaQons for the project as well as links to where those specificaQons can be found on Wednesday. We also provided the esQmate although we disagree as to what the term “esQmate” is defined as. The esQmate is required to be provided by the engineer so that he can assure his client as to what the probable cost will be for the project so that the client will know if it is within their budget and they can proceed with construcQon of the project.
The calculaQons that you have requested simply do not exist. I have checked with the engineer that designed these construcQon plans and the only calculaQons that they performed are the drainage calculaQons which are found in the plans. As I previously stated, design of the roadway is based upon design criteria provided in the AASHTO green book, the City of AusQn TransportaQon Criteria Manual (which the City of Cedar Park has adopted), and TxDOT’s Design Manual. These manuals are used as a basis for the cross secQon design of the roadway as well as the geometric design of the roadway. These design criteria are used by transportaQon engineers throughout Texas and the United States.
I was hoping to relay this informaQon and discuss it further with you during our 9:00 meeQng yesterday at your house. We met with your wife instead and measured and verified that the dimensions shown on the plans are correct and meet the design criteria shown in the design manuals.
I noQced that you have CC’ed LeAnn Quinn on your email. I would suggest contacQng Ms. Quinn directly and she can help you through the open records request process. Please let me know if you have any addiQonal quesQons.

Let address some of the issues that you menQon below.
First, the distance from the roadway to the property line is measured from the face of curb of the through lane, not the right turn lane. As I menQoned in my earlier email, it is measured that way because the vehicles traveling in the right turn lane are deceleraQng.
Second, we have not lied, hidden informaQon or misled you in any way. In the drawing you have zoomed into below, your property line is the dashed one below the bold line that is labeled as
             Page 1607 of 1607

   the handrail. The handrail is not located on the property line. There are several feet between your property line and the sidewalk. The wooden stake that you show in your picture is an offset stake, not where the edge of the roadway is going to be.
Third, the 12 foot siÄng right in the middle is there to keep opposing lanes of traffic separated. These medians are used on most of our arterial roadways.
Fourth, I am not sure what specs and calculaQons you are looking for. The roadway cross secQons can be found in the City of AusQn’s TransportaQon Criteria Manual which the City of Cedar Park has adopted. The cross secQons and other design parameters are what the design engineer uses to design the roadways as they are based upon the AASHTO (American AssociaQon of State Highway TransportaQon Officials) design manual. This manual is used all over the United States by professional engineers.
